PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE  PAPER 
I.  BACKGROUND AND RATIONALE 
 
A.  Background 
 
1.  The Philippine electrical power grid, with about 15,681 MW of installed capacity in 2008, 
is divided into three: Luzon (Northern Philippines), Visayas (Central Philippines), and Mindanao 
(Southern Philippines). The Luzon grid, where the three wind farm projects will be located, is the 
largest of the three grids and accounts for over 75% of the total installed capacity. Fossil fueled 
power plants, which are largely located in Luzon, is the dominant source with coal-fired power 
plants  and  oil  fired  power  plants  accounting  for  26.9%  and  21.4%  of  installed  capacity 
respectively. Total power generated in 2008 was at 60,281 GWh, of which roughly 66.1% is 
from fossil fuel. Natural gas-fired power plants remain the top producer of electricity with a total 
generation of 19,576 GWh while coal-fired generation was the second leading contributor with a 
generation of 15,749 GWh. Oil-based plants generated a total of 4,868 GWh in 2008. Almost all 
of the coal and oil required to run the power plants is imported, thus exposing the country to 
price volatility and the availability of fuel supply. In 2007, the country spent roughly $7.5 billion to 
import fossil fuel for power generation.  
 
2.  In the meantime, greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions in the country have been rising 
because a significant portion of the country's energy requirements are supplied by coal and oil. 
In 2005, the Philippines was ranked 39th in the world in terms of overall GHG emissions with 
about 142 million tons of carbon dioxide equivalent (MtCO e), excluding emissions due to land 
2
use change.1 Studies done by ADB (2009)2 and World Bank (2009)3 indicate that under a 
business-as-usual scenario in which half of the installed capacity will be coal-fired plants, total 
GHG emissions from power generation will increase from less than 30 to about 140 MtCO e/y 
2
(representing more than a 400% increase by 2030).4  The Philippines therefore is faced with the 
challenge of achieving energy security in an environmentally sustainable manner in its pursuit of 
economic growth. 
 
3.  Recognizing the challenges faced by the country, the energy road map, approved in 
2008 by the then Philippine President, promotes technology shifts to mitigate the increase in 
GHG  emissions  particularly  in  the  power  sector.  In  accordance  with  the  road  map,  the 
Government signed into law the Renewable Energy Act (RE Act) in December 2008, which is 
designed to encourage increasing use of renewable energy in power generation with the aim to 
double the renewable based installed capacity from its 2008 level of 5,300 MW by 2030. Key 
components of the RE Act, which are the determination of the Feed-in-Tariffs, Renewable 
Portfolio Standard, and Net Metering are currently in the final stages of deliberation and is 
anticipated to be released soon. The Government is optimistic that once the incentives for

4.  The potential for wind power is abundant since the country is situated on the fringes of 
the Asia-Pacific monsoonal belt. A study conducted by the US National Renewable Energy 
Laboratory (NREL) in 1999 shows over 10,000 square kms of windy land area exist with a 
combined capacity of about 70,000 MW. Despite the enormous potential however, only one 
wind power project, Northwind Bangui Bay power plant5, has been developed with an installed 
capacity of 33 MW. This is due largely to the cost of developing and constructing wind power 
plants particularly in a merchant market environment6. The private sector views the barriers to 
entry to be high and considers the cost of doing site-specific feasibility studies including wind 
assessments  prohibitive  due  to  the  probability  that  such  initial  investment  could  indicate 
unfavorable business prospects. 
  
B.    Technical Assistance 
 
5.  In December 2008, Alternergy Philippine Holdings Corporation (APHC) was awarded by 
the Department of Energy the exclusive right to develop wind power projects in 3 locations. In 
accordance with the RE Act, this right was subsequently converted to wind energy service 
contract which gives APHC the exclusive right to develop and construct wind power projects in 
those locations. These locations were among those identified under the Philippine Wind Atlas as 
potential sites for wind farms due to good to excellent wind resources. Subsequently, DOE 
awarded additional wind energy service contracts to APHC in 3 other locations in October 2009. 
APHC is committed to implement all six projects if the wind measurements and site specific 
studies indicate that the power plants are commercially viable. Given the high costs of preparing 
comprehensive feasibility studies for each site, APHC has sought the assistance of ADB to 
advance the payment for these costs for the 3 initial locations. APHC will simultaneously finance 
the feasibility studies for the 3 new sites. 
 
6.  The proposed technical assistance will be provided to APHC to conduct the first phase 
of the preparatory work for the construction of three wind power projects. The TA will produce 
the site-specific feasibility studies including wind assessment for each of the three proposed 
wind power plants. Each feasibility study would determine the viability for commercial operations 
of a wind power project which would be needed by APHC to raise financing for the construction 
and operation of these power plants. 
 
7.  Key activities under the TA will include: (i) develop basic concept for layout of wind farm; 
(ii) detailed design of the wind monitoring program; (iii) monitor, collect, and analyze wind data, 
ensuring quality control of the reference station; (iv) select and specify wind turbine generator 
sets; (v) calculate standard wind farm energy production, optimize wind farm grid based on 
technical data analysis; (vi) calculate wind farm construction and development costs, analyze 
technical risks, sensitivity analysis; (vii) conduct environmental and social impact assessments, 
including public consultations with affected persons (in partnership with local organizations); and 
(viii) develop an interconnection plan to evacuate the power from each project to the main

Luzon grid. After completion of the feasibility studies, so long as the studies indicate that the 
projects are technically and financially viable, APHC would commence the construction of the 
three wind power projects with a combined capacity of up to 150 MW. 
 
C.    Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 
 
8.  ADB's country strategy and program for the Philippines lists inadequate infrastructure 
such as the availability of reliable and affordable electricity as among the six major constraints 
for the country to achieve rapid poverty reduction. Given the country's fiscal imbalance, ADB, 
through the Power Sector Development Program (PSDP), supports Government initiatives that 
increase private sector investments to increase and improve the delivery of electricity in the 
country. Support for the development of wind power plants by APHC, a private sector company, 
is a logical continuation of ADB's PSDP initiatives. 
 
9.  ADB recognizes that energy plays a vital role in economic growth and poverty reduction 
and is taking a prominent role to help countries like the Philippines, which is heavily reliant on 
imported  coal  and  oil,  achieve  energy  security  while  mitigating  the  country's  growing 
greenhouse gas emissions. As such, ADB is integrating climate change into planning and 
investment, to ensure continued economic growth in a sustainable manner. The proposed wind 
power  projects  are  in  line  with  ADB's  climate  change  initiatives  that  promote  the  use  of 
renewable energy to support the economy. 
 
D.    Cost Estimates and Proposed Financing Arrangements 
 
10.  ADB will provide up to $630,000 on a grant basis from the Asian Clean Energy Fund7 
under the Clean Energy Financing Partnership Facility.  
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
11.  Executing  Agency. APHC will be the Executing Agency of this PPTA. APHC is a 
company  founded  by  individuals  with  extensive  experience  in  power  development  in  the 
Philippines and renewable energy. The key individuals behind this company are Vincent S. 
Perez, Jr. and Knud Hedeager. Mr. Perez was the Philippine Energy Minister from June 2001 to 
March 2005 where he aggressively pursued and promoted energy self-sufficiency and use of 
clean indigenous energy.  He was instrumental in crafting the country's renewable energy policy 
framework. Mr. Perez is currently one of the members of the National Renewable Energy 
Board8, representing the non-government organization (NGO) sector. Mr. Hedeager, on the 
other hand has worked in the wind industry for the past 7 years initially as a senior management

12.  In September 2009, the principals behind APHC agreed to a joint venture arrangement 
whereby Alternergy Philippine Investments Corporation (APIC) will own 40% of the equity while 
Alternergy El Viento Partners Corporation (AVPC), a company owned by Mr. Perez will own 
60%.  The joint venture arrangements indicate that APIC will hold only common stocks while 
AVPC will hold only preferred shares. Korea East-West Power Company, Ltd (EWP), Eurus 
Energy Japan Corporation (Eurus Japan) hold 99.99% of APIC in equal portion with the balance 
held by AVPC.  
 
13.  Eurus Japan is wholly-owned by Eurus Energy Holdings Corporation which is in turn 
owned by Tokyo Electric Power Company (60%) and Toyota Tsusho Corporation (40%). The 
Eurus group owns and operates approximately 1,800 MW of wind and solar power plants in 
Japan, Korea, USA and Europe. EWP is one of six power producers spun off from Korea 
Electric  Power  Corporation  (KEPCO)  in  2001  as  part  of  the  restructuring  plan  of  the 
government.    EWP  remains  wholly-owned  by  KEPCO  and  currently  operates  an  installed 
capacity of 9,500 MW.  The senior management of EWP has extensive experience in the 
Philippine  power  industry,  having  been  assigned  in  previous  years  to  oversee  KEPCO 
Philippines Corporation. 
 
14.  Arrangements. ADB will engage the consultants for this PPTA in accordance with The 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (April 2010, as amended from time to time) and other 
arrangements satisfactory to ADB. 
 
15.  The proposed PPTA will engage and finance a total of 27.0 person-months (PM) of 
consulting services of an international firm (or 8.5 person-months of consulting services per 
wind  farm)  consisting  of  21  PM  of  international  and  6  PM  of  national  consultants.  The 
assignment will be on an intermittent basis over a two year period beginning on 1 October 2010. 
The quality-cost based selection method and simplified technical proposals will be used in 
recruiting the consulting firm that would perform the scope of work outlined in Appendix 2. The 
technical proposals will be given a weight of 80% and the financial proposals a weight of 20%. 
Advance contracting has been initiated to ensure that the PPTA will be ready for implementation 
by  October  2010.  Disbursements  under  the  TA  will  be  made  in  accordance  with  ADB's 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (May 2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
16.  APHC has been informed that approval of this PPTA does not commit ADB to finance 
any ensuing project; however ADB will be given the right of first refusal to provide financing to 
all or any of the three wind power plants under terms and conditions acceptable to ADB. 
 
17.  APHC understands that the amount advanced by ADB to conduct a feasibility study will 
be recovered by ADB, should the PPTA lead to a subsequent financing for any of the three 
projects under this TA. The recovery mechanism to be implemented will be in accordance with 
ADB policies on technical assistance9. If the ensuing project however is not implemented by 
APHC after an agreed period of time, the TA information will become a knowledge product 
which can be disclosed and shared with others. 
                                                
9 OM Section D12/BP issued on 18 May 2010, para 30 states that nonsovereign TA will be subject to 
arrangements providing for recovery of the full cost of the PPTA to the extent that the TA results in further 
financial assistance from ADB.

18.  Complementary Inputs. APHC will also provide the necessary office accommodation, 
counterpart staff and related facilities. 
 
F.  Recommendation 
 
19.  Pursuant  to  the  Increasing  the  Impact  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank’s  Technical 
Assistance Program Policy (Board paper R87-08) which has delegated authority to approve 
project  preparatory  technical  assistance  of  up  to  $1.5  million  to  vice  presidents,  the  Vice 
President (Private Sector and Cofinancing Operations) and the Vice President (Operations 2) 
have  approved  the  provision  of  a  technical  assistance  to  Alternergy  Philippine  Holdings 
Corporation to be financed on a grant basis by the Asian Clean Energy Fund under the Clean 
Energy Financing Partnership Facility for preparing Three Wind Farm Projects in Luzon. This 
action will be reported to the Board in the Quarterly Summary Report. In accordance with the 
Board  paper  on  Review  of  the  Management  and  Effectiveness  of  Technical  Assistance 
Operations of the Asian Development Bank10, this technical assistance will be financed initially 
as a grant, but will be subject to arrangements that will seek recovery of the amount financed 
under the technical assistance should the envisaged projects be implemented.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will finance the cost of conducting a feasibility study (FS) for 
three wind farm projects with a combined installed capacity of up to 150 MW. 
 
2.  The implementation of the FS will require the services of an international consulting firm.  
The FS will require 9.0 person-months of consulting services per wind farm site or a total of 27.0 
person-months consisting of 21 person-months of international and 6 person-months of national 
consultants. The assignment will be on an intermittent basis over a two year period beginning on 1 
October 2010. It is expected that the technical team of the international consulting firm will consist 
of Senior Renewable Energy Consultant(s), Renewable Energy Consultant(s), Renewable Energy 
Manager(s) / Team Leader(s), Renewable Energy Environmental Specialist(s), and Renewable 
Transmission Specialist(s).  The scope of work for the consulting services will include but not be 
limited to the following: 
 
3.  Senior Renewable Energy Consultant(s) (international, 3.5 person-months per wind farm 
project) 
 
(i)  Conduct preliminary wind resource modeling at wind farm sites to provide a basis for 
the  deployment  of  wind  monitoring  towers,  field  supervision  of  wind  monitoring  station 
installation,  sensor  attachment,  alignment,  cabling,  data  logger  commissioning,  and 
verification of data communications.  Provide data compilation and quality control. 
(ii)  Gather information on all development issues of the potential wind farms through 
characterizing the sites from a land use and wind resource perspective 
(iii)  Identify construction conditions to determine designs in minimizing environmental 
impacts and assessing costs for equipment access and installation 
(iv)  Verify and confirm the wind climate to determine turbine choices, design of the wind 
farm layouts and boundaries, and overall economics of renewable energy power sales to the 
grid 
(v)  Calculate a detailed wind turbine class to define conditions within which equipment 
will be required to operate, define equipment choices and terms, conditions, and warranties 
that may have to be addressed in contracts with manufacturers 
(vi)  Write technical specifications and match these with suitable terms and conditions for 
the wind turbine transportation studies 
(vii)  Review Site Investigation report for micro-siting purposes and assess if any further 
SI works are required to complete the wind farm design 
(viii)  Ensure technical feasibility of the construction and minimize capital costs of civil and 
electrical infrastructure as far as possible 
(ix)  Optimize layout with due consideration of constraint zones required to minimize 
interference with other site users 
(x)  Assist the local environmental consultants and authorities with any technical input 
that they may require about the design or operation of the potential wind farms 
(xi)  Conduct a desktop study using an ETSU R-97 noise model to predict the noise 
levels at local sensitive receptors for the wind farm site 
(xii)  Conduct of background noise monitoring – measurement of existing background 
noise at the sensitive receptors and collecting data for 3-4 weeks 
(xiii)  Prepare a Noise Analysis Report with map contours showing the expected noise 
levels in and around the wind farm 
(xiv)  Conduct a site visit and identify the affected properties and areas that need to be 
modeled for visual impact from shadow flicker 
(xv)  Generate six (6) separate viewing angles for each of the following types of simulation

I.  POVERTY ISSUES 
A.  Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy 
1.  Based on the country poverty assessment, the country partnership strategy and the sector analysis describe how the 
project would directly or indirectly contribute to poverty reduction and how it is linked to the poverty reduction strategy of 
the partner country. 
 
ADB's Country Strategy and Program in the Philippines (2005-2007) calls for interventions to address several 
constraints to more rapid poverty reduction in the Philippines. The proposed technical assistance to develop 3 
wind power projects will help address three of these constraints, namely (i) fiscal imbalance by facilitating 
private sector investments in the power sector; (ii) inadequate infrastructure by augmenting power generation 
infrastructure through the construction of new power plants; and (iii) poor management of resources by 
providing an efficient and clean source of power.  The Project is also consistent with the Country Operations 
Business Plan (2009-2010) which identified renewable energy infrastructure projects as one of the targets for 
private sector operations investments. It is also expected to increase power generation from renewable energy 
sources in the Philippines, in line with the objectives of the 2008 Renewal Energy Act (RA 9153). 
 
B.     Targeting Classification          
1.  Select the targeting classification of the project:

2.   Explain the basis for the targeting classification:  
 
The Project is expected to indirectly alleviate poverty in the local communities where the projects will be 
located through the development of livelihood projects and supply of stable electricity. Reliable power supply 
from alternative energy sources will improve living conditions particularly in poor villages by reducing the use 
of diesel powered generators. The Project is also expected to provide employment opportunities to local 
residents where the wind farms will be constructed.

governance, and pro-poor growth)?  Host community benefit program. 
 
The 3 projects shall each be designed such that any affected persons may also benefit from the project. 
 
II.  SOCIAL DEVELOPMENT ISSUES 
A.  Initial Social Analysis 
Based on existing information: 
1. Who are the potential primary beneficiaries of the project? How do the poor and the socially excluded benefit from the 
project?   
 
The project is expected to create opportunities for employment during construction and operations. Migration of workers, 
population is expected to be minimum as qualified local workers from the nearby barangays will be preferred.  Moreover, 
as part of the private sector sponsor’s commitment to corporate social responsibility, community development projects 
will be developed in consultation with the local community.

Adverse social impacts are expected to be limited. Impacts and mitigation measures are being identified in the ongoing 
assessments. If involuntary resettlement impacts are identified, the appropriate resettlement planning document will be 
prepared in accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009).  If involuntary resettlement impacts are

3. What are the potential constraints in accessing the proposed benefits and services, and how will the project address 
them? 
 
Local residents may need training or skill enhancements to improve their potential for employment in any work 
opportunities generated by the project. 
 
B.  Consultation and Participation 
1. Indicate the potential initial stakeholders.  
 
Potential initial stakeholders include national and local government units, communities within the vicinity of the project 
site, and community and nongovernment organizations. 
 
2. What type of consultation and participation (C&P) is required during the PPTA or project processing (e.g., workshops, 
community mobilization, involvement of nongovernment organizations and community-based organizations, etc.)?  
 
The project has already been discussed by private sector sponsor with Department of Energy and the Department of 
Environment and Natural Resources prior to agreeing on the wind energy service contract and the land use certificate, 
respectively.  Additional consultations will be held with local communities and affected persons as part of the feasibility 
study for each wind farm project and in accordance with national laws. APHC will ensure that consultation and 
disclosure activities also meet ADB’s Public Communications Policy (2005) requirements in the event that the project is 
considered for ADB financing.
